Award.AwardTitle: Differential Geometry and Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project lies at the interface between Differential Geometry, General Relativity, and Partial Differential Equations. One theme will be the study of manifolds of positive curvature. Specifically the proposer plans to further his study of manifolds of positive isotropic curvature (PIC) using Ricci flow and minimal surface techniques. He also hopes to prove sphere theorems under pointwise pinching conditions with pinching slightly below 1/4. In relativity he plans to study the geometry of static matter solutions hoping to show that matter bodies cannot be separated by convex sets in such solutions. He also plans to study the general Penrose inequality; that is, the conjectured inequality for black hole initial sets with nonzero second fundamental form. He will also pursue a range of questions concerning minimal submanifolds satisfying free boundary conditions and connections to eigenvalue problems. Finally he plans to continue his study of minimal lagrangian and special lagrangian submanifolds of Kahler-Einstein manifolds. He will attempt to prove a conjecture concerning the invariance of the subgroup of the integral homology of a Calabi-Yau manifold which is generated by minimal lagrangian cycles when one deforms the ambient Calabi-Yau structure.

Understanding spaces in terms of their curvature properties is a fundamental idea in mathematics and science. The laws of nature often provide information about curvature properties, and from those we must deduce information about the spaces. A prime example of this is General Relativity where the equations of motion are described by curvature, and from those we must determine concrete properties of the universe. This project deals with a range of questions of this type such as the way in which black holes form from smooth initial data. Furthermore, geometry is important in application areas such as imaging and computer graphics. The research of this project will advance the core geometric ideas which form the basis of such applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main work supported by this project was in the areas of mathematical general relativity and spectral geometry. In relativity there were two main results obtained. The first concerned the spacetime positive mass theorem. The positive mass theorem is a basic result for the Einstein equations which asserts that physically realistic gravitational systems have positive mass and will therefore attract each other. Mathematically it is a geometric theorem which imposes conditions on the asymptotic behavior of quite general solutions of the Einstein equations. In relativity the mass is the length of the spacetime energy-momentum vector, so the positivity of energy is technically a weaker statement than the statement that the energy-momentum vector is a forward pointing timelike vector. One outcome of this project was a proof that this spacetime positive mass theorem is true even for higher dimensional spacetimes (up to dimension seven). The interest of gravity in higher dimensions is motivated from physics by considerations in string theory and in mathematics by geometric considerations. Prior to this work the result was only known for manifolds which have a spin structure, a topological condition on the spacetime.

A second work in relativity which came out of this project concerned the relationship between mass and angular momentum. A very important family of exact solutions in general relativity is the Kerr family of solutions which model stationary rotating black holes. In this family there is a mass parameter and an anglular momentum parameter. In order for the solution to exist as a physically reasonable solution the angular momentum must be less than or equal to the mass. The idea is that if the black hole is spinning at too rapid a rate for its mass, it would fly apart and could not represent a stationary solution. The question of whether the Kerr solutions have the largest possible angular momentum for their mass among dynamical (non-stationary) solutions is an old question in the subject. It is a question which concerns axisymmetric solutions of the Einstein equations for which the angular momentum is a local quantity defined by a flux integral. An outcome of this project was a quantitative theorem of this type which gives a lower bound on the difference between the mass and angular momentum by a positive expression which measures the difference between the given metric and the Kerr metric.

Spectral geometry concerns the study of the relationship of the spectrum (eigenvalues of the Laplace operator) to the geometry of the underlying space. These eigenvalues represent the fundamental vibrational frequencies for the space considered as a perfectly elastic vibrating membrane. They are of great physical and also geometric significance. An outcome of this project was an understanding of the geometry of curved surfaces which maximize the lowest eigenvalue for their area (or boundary length). In the case of a sphere the maximizer is known to be a perfectly round sphere as opposed to any other shape with the same area. It is less clear what the maximizer should be for other surfaces such as a torus or a sphere with many handles. In this project this question was answered for a large class of surfaces with boundary. In this case the eigenvalues are taken to be those with respect to a particular boundary condition (Steklov eigenvalues). The maximizer for a disk has been known to be the round disk, but the PI was able to explicitly determine the maximizer for an annulus. This was shown to be a very special annulus called the critical catenoid, a portion of the surface of revolution gotten by revolving the hyperbolic cosine curve around an axis. It was also shown for a disk with any number of holes (any surface of genus zero) the maximizing metric exists as the metric on a special type of surface in space, and that, as the number of holes becomes large, the asymptotic behavior of the maximizing eigenvalue and the metric can be determined.
